breaking_news.title: DKnife Linux Toolkit Hijacks Router Traffic for AitM Espionage
breaking_news.summary:
A newly discovered Linux-based toolkit named DKnife has been actively used since 2019 by China-linked threat actors to perform adversary-in-the-middle (AitM) attacks by hijacking traffic at the router and edge-device level. The toolkit comprises seven implants that enable deep packet inspection, traffic manipulation, and malware delivery, primarily targeting telecom providers, ISPs, government, and defense sectors.


The campaign demonstrates a sophisticated, long-running infrastructure-level compromise that bypasses traditional endpoint security. By operating at the network edge, attackers gain persistent visibility into encrypted traffic and can pivot laterally into high-value networks, significantly expanding the attack surface beyond conventional malware delivery methods.

breaking_news.title: SmarterMail RCE Flaw CVE-2026-24423 Actively Exploited in Ransomware Attacks
breaking_news.summary:
CISA has issued an urgent advisory about CVE-2026-24423, an unauthenticated remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability in SmarterMail email servers, which is actively being exploited in ransomware attacks. The flaw allows attackers to execute arbitrary code without authentication, enabling rapid deployment of ransomware payloads across unpatched mail infrastructure.


With SmarterMail widely used by mid-sized businesses and government agencies, this vulnerability poses immediate risk to email systems globally. CISA added the flaw to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, mandating federal agencies patch within 14 days—highlighting the severity and active exploitation态势.

breaking_news.title: State-Backed APT Targets 155 Countries in 'Shadow Campaigns' Espionage Operation
breaking_news.summary:
A previously undocumented state-aligned threat group, tracked as TGR-STA-1030/UNC6619, has launched a global cyberespionage campaign dubbed 'Shadow Campaigns,' targeting government infrastructure across 155 countries. The group has compromised at least 70 entities in 37 countries since 2025, using custom malware, zero-day exploits, and supply chain techniques to maintain persistence.


The scale and sophistication of the operation—spanning diplomatic missions, defense contractors, and critical infrastructure—indicates a high-impact, long-term espionage effort. This campaign represents one of the most geographically extensive state-sponsored intrusions ever documented, with implications for international security and data sovereignty.

breaking_news.title: Substack Breach Exposes 700K Users After Months-Long Intrusion
breaking_news.summary:
Newsletter platform Substack confirmed a data breach after a hacker leaked nearly 700,000 user records—including email addresses, phone numbers, and account metadata—on a cybercrime forum. The breach occurred in October 2025 but went undetected for months before Substack disclosed it on February 5, 2026. Passwords and financial data were not compromised.


Substack serves tens of thousands of writers and over 35 million readers globally, making this a high-profile breach affecting prominent journalists, authors, and influencers. The delayed detection underscores weaknesses in third-party monitoring and incident response, raising concerns about data handling in SaaS ecosystems.

breaking_news.title: Betterment Suffers Social Engineering Breach Exposing 1.4M Users
breaking_news.summary:
Automated investment platform Betterment disclosed a breach affecting approximately 1.4 million users after attackers used social engineering to gain internal access in January 2026. The compromise exposed email addresses, phone numbers, and other personal information, though financial and account credentials remained secure.


As a major fintech firm managing billions in assets, the breach highlights the growing reliance on human-based attack vectors to bypass technical defenses. The incident underscores the need for enhanced identity verification and internal access controls, especially in regulated sectors handling sensitive financial data.

breaking_news.title: Italian University La Sapienza Offline After Ransomware Attack
breaking_news.summary:
Rome’s La Sapienza University, one of Europe’s largest academic institutions, remains offline since February 2, 2026, following a ransomware attack that disrupted core IT services. Students cannot access exam booking, tuition systems, or faculty directories, and the university has resorted to social media for limited communication. The shutdown was ordered as a precaution to contain the attack.


The prolonged outage demonstrates the operational paralysis ransomware can cause in critical public institutions. As a major research hub, the breach risks academic continuity, data integrity, and international collaborations—highlighting vulnerabilities in university cybersecurity posture and incident recovery planning.

breaking_news.title: CISA Mandates Removal of Unsupported Edge Devices Within 18 Months
breaking_news.summary:
CISA issued Binding Operational Directive 26-02, requiring all U.S. federal civilian agencies to identify and replace end-of-support edge network devices—such as routers, firewalls, and switches—within 12 to 18 months. The directive aims to reduce technical debt and eliminate known vulnerabilities exploited by state-sponsored actors targeting legacy infrastructure.


This policy reflects growing concern over unpatched edge devices as high-value targets for nation-state actors. With over 100,000 such devices likely in federal use, the mandate represents a major shift in federal cybersecurity lifecycle management and sets a precedent for critical infrastructure sectors.

breaking_news.title: Compromised dYdX npm and PyPI Packages Deliver Crypto Wallet Stealers
breaking_news.summary:
Cybersecurity researchers discovered a supply chain attack compromising legitimate packages on npm and PyPI—specifically @dydxprotocol/v4-client-js—deploying malicious versions that steal wallet credentials and install remote access trojans (RATs). The attack leverages trust in open-source dependencies to target developers and crypto users.


This incident exemplifies the rising threat of supply chain compromises in developer tooling ecosystems. With the dYdX brand associated with a major decentralized exchange, the attack has high potential for financial theft and erodes confidence in open-source package integrity across blockchain and fintech sectors.

breaking_news.title: German Agencies Warn of Signal Phishing Targeting Politicians and Military
breaking_news.summary:
Germany’s BfV and BSI jointly warned of a state-sponsored phishing campaign using the Signal messaging app to compromise high-value targets, including politicians, military personnel, and journalists. Attackers impersonate trusted contacts and exploit Signal’s perceived security to deliver credential-harvesting links or malware.


The use of Signal—a platform trusted for end-to-end encryption—demonstrates evolving attacker tradecraft that leverages platform trust and social engineering to bypass technical defenses. This campaign signals a strategic shift toward high-fidelity, low-volume targeting of elite individuals for intelligence gathering.

breaking_news.title: Record-Breaking 31.4 Tbps DDoS Attack Observed by Cloudflare
breaking_news.summary:
Cloudflare mitigated a record-breaking 31.4 Tbps DDoS attack in November 2025—launched by the AISURU/Kimwolf botnet—that lasted only 35 seconds. This hyper-volumetric HTTP flood marked a 700% increase in large attack sizes compared to late 2024 and represents the largest volumetric DDoS ever publicly documented.


The attack underscores the exponential growth in botnet scale and the increasing use of automated, short-duration floods designed to overwhelm mitigation systems before detection. While Cloudflare absorbed the impact, such attacks threaten less-resourced targets and highlight the need for adaptive, AI-driven DDoS defenses.
